text: The Beluga Liner is the largest ship in the Saud Kruger line after the Dolphin and Orca, designed for luxury passenger transport with a focus on comfort and maneuverability over speed and cargo capacity.

The Beluga Liner features a Class 7 Frame Shift Drive and a 128-tonne Fuel Tank, providing an impressive travel range for long-distance cruises. It can also fit a Fighter Hangar for modest offensive capability.
As a trading ship, the Beluga Liner has 368t of potential cargo space, which is relatively poor compared to other large ships like the Type-9 Heavy.

The Beluga Liner is an interesting option for exploration, with a jump range of 40-50 ly when equipped with a Guardian Frame Shift Drive Booster. It offers ample internal space and the ability to equip a Fighter Hangar.
The Beluga Liner performs poorly in combat due to its large size, weak shields, and ineffective hardpoint placement, making it vulnerable despite its Fighter Hangar.
The Beluga Liner is highly specialized as a passenger liner but suffers from limitations such as heat management issues, a large size complicating docking, and a suboptimal shield generator.
The Beluga Liner has dimensions of 209.1m x 131.6m x 38.6m, a hull mass of 950 tonnes, and a top speed of 197 m/s (default) or 230 m/s (upgraded).
The Beluga Liner has a default cargo capacity of 44 tonnes, which can be expanded to a maximum of 370 tonnes.
The Beluga Liner is manufactured by Saud Kruger and has been in production since 3302. It is a passenger liner with a cost of 84,532,780 CR and insurance of 4,226,639 CR.
The Beluga Liner features 6x Utility Mounts and 5x Medium Hardpoints, with internal compartments including 1x Class 1, 4x Class 3, 1x Class 4, 2x Class 5, and 4x Class 6 compartments.
The Beluga Liner's default outfitting includes Pulse Lasers on its medium hardpoints and various internal systems such as a Shield Generator, Cargo Racks, and Passenger Cabins.
